journal-title-group.journal-title: Journal of developmental and behavioral pediatrics : JDBP

title-group.article-title: Creatine Transporter Deficiency: Screening of Males with Neurodevelopmental Disorders and Neurocognitive Characterization of a Case

article-meta.aff: 1Pediatrics and Developmental Neuroscience Branch, National Institute of Mental Health, National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, MD 20892, USA

author-notes.corresp: *Corresponding author: Audrey Thurm, 10 Center Drive, Rm 1C250, MSC 1255, Bethesda, MD 20892, Office: 301-496-5323, Fax: 301-402-8497, athurm@mail.nih.gov

fn.p: We report no conflicts of interest from any of the authors.

sec.title: Objective
sec.p: Creatine Transporter Deficiency (CTD) is an X-linked, neurometabolic disorder associated with intellectual disability that is characterized by brain creatine deficiency and caused by mutations in SLC6A8, the creatine transporter 1 protein gene. CTD is identified by elevated urine creatine/creatinine ratio or reduced creatine peak on brain magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS); the diagnosis is confirmed by decreased creatine uptake in cultured fibroblasts, and/or identification of a mutation in the SLC6A8 gene. Prevalence studies suggest this disorder may be underdiagnosed. We sought to identify cases from a well-characterized cohort of children diagnosed with neurodevelopmental disorders.

sec.title: Method
sec.p: Urine screening for CTD was performed on a cohort of 46 males with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and 9 males with a history of non-ASD developmental delay classified with intellectual disability.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: We identified one patient with CTD in the cohort based on abnormal urine creatine/creatinine, and confirmed the diagnosis by the identification of a novel frameshift mutation in the SLC6A8 gene. This patient presented without ASD but with intellectual disability, and was characterized by a non-specific phenotype of early language and developmental delay that persisted into moderate-to-severe intellectual disability, consistent with previous descriptions of CTD.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Identification of patients with CTD is possible by measuring urine creatine and creatinine levels and the current case adds to the growing literature of neurocognitive deficits associated with the disorder affecting cognition, language and behavior in childhood.
